author: @i2dorky
text: I was raped by my ex boyfriend of 5-6 years (on and off) and the night it happened was the same day I tried to commit suicide because of the (mental) abuse I was going through in our relationship. I hid it away from a lot of people that he did this until later on and still got attacked and ignored. I ended up finding out he's done this before to an ex and finally found the courage to talk to the police (after house hopping and literally being doxxed and harassed by this side gig I was holding onto). Just to get turned down because I "willingly slept in the bed with him when it happened" and I dont know what to do with myself now. This video genuinely helped me see Im not alone bc sometimes I think abt suicide a lot because I feel like this world just hates me bc Im a black woman. Because I should he aggressive or demanding or assertive when Im really just scared and unloved. Thank you again for speaking for victims, seriously we need more videos like this.

replies.text:
@i2dorky I hope you‚Äôre able to find some sources of healing and comfort. No one deserves to feel that level of violation and trauma from someone they loved and trusted. The fact that you‚Äôre still alive is incredible (as of your reply three days ago which I was relieved to see)!!

All this is to say, I see you, I hear your story, and you‚Äôre not alone. I‚Äôm just a stranger, but I‚Äôm rooting for you! I hope you have folks irl to share love and support too because you deserve that softness and healing. I don‚Äôt even know you and you‚Äôve managed to help me recontextualize my own pains. If your courage to share your story here is any indication, you bring so much light into the world.

If you‚Äôd like to know any parts of my story to help feel less alone, I also slept in the same bed, curled up and faced away from, as my abuser the night he sexually assaulted me. This boundary stomping was the pinnacle of weeks of emotional abuse and shaming me for a mistake. During that same period, the same man threatened to sue me, and he had tax-backers-worth of power compared to me. Not only did he leverage his wealth and the judicial system, he had to violate me too. That was back in 2018.

It‚Äôs taken me years to sift through those layers of pain in order to empathize with myself so that I could start to heal. I know it‚Äôll be a lifelong process, but I wanted to share that your story matters. replies.author: @mjbset93
replies.text: As a black man that has never put his hands on a woman, this video, made me sad, confused, and convicted.  In a lot of these public cases I have to admit a level of frustration with these women continuing relationships with these men.   Not logical but when I was young I found it particularly devastating when a couple of girls I liked chose to be with guys that abused them psychologically and physically over me.  And now that I am older happily married it is still hard to understand the abusive relationship dynamics.  So many broken people in the world just linking up and passing down generational trauma bond relationship building.  What could I tell my son (even if he shared that pain with me because I didn't with ANYONE for a decade after it happened) if he thought he was in love with a woman who chose an abuser over him?  Give him a psychology book about it he probably won't read or simply say woman she thinks is so special is just a regular broken human being, would that help?  And worse yet my niece has spent a lot of her adult life in abusive relationships.   But I only found out about them years after.  I feel pretty powerless to make difference beyond raising my boys to men the way I have.  Black women are just the most spectacular people on the face of the earth individually.  We have to do better.

replies.author: @tracer4322
replies.text: This is fear is so valid and it's something I've grappled with myself. I studied domestic violence in school and I learned that it truly can happen to anyone, even people that are educated about DV and have the resources to get out. That said, there are warning signs that you can learn about to protect yourself and the people around you. Some include misogynistic beliefs, controlling behaviors or comments (like what you're wearing for example), and isolation from friends/family (most important one- this is the first tactic of a DV perpetrator). I'd highly recommend educating yourself about DV because it's a great tool for prevention

author: @pretty.bird0306
text: During one of my beatings, a neighbor called the police. My kids father forced me to answer the door, so I did. I didn‚Äôt realize I was bleeding. Telling them with my mouth that I was ok, but pleading with them not to leave with my eyes was scary. I knew it wasn‚Äôt over yet, and I was afraid what might happen. But I was even more afraid for him. I didn‚Äôt want him to go to jail, I just wanted him to stop hurting me. I wanted him to love me. This is the damaged psyche of a domestic violence victim. I am so sorry that you had to experience that during what is supposed to be one of the best times of your life. You did not deserve any of it.

replies.text: To me, firstly, those aren't reasons to blame Meg (not that I think they are for you, I'm just mad about the hypocrisy). Anyone should be allowed to be drunk, and even angry, and never expect violence to break out. There should definitely never be violence during intimacy. Secondly, though, I just think sometimes people will always blame victims, and especially black women who are victims, just because they are victims. We all want to think that there's a way to avoid being victims of crime, but sometimes there isn't, and when that happens, we blame the victims for reminding us of that fact.

My own mom defended my abuser, even when he tried to get custody of my child - a child who wasn't his and he knew that. He lied to police when my neighbors intervened and they believed him - even while I had handprint bruises covering me. My rocking chair, the glider I used to nurse  my baby had a broken back because he'd put it in front of my closet while trying to lock me up. The cops said it wasn't there and that I should be arrested for trying to inflict harm on this "young, innocent white man." They literally told me that. Meanwhile, I was the only person thinking of my daughter and how to keep her safe - because he had thrown her in a dark room, half naked when he attacked me.She was screaming and sobbing and all I could think of was how was I going to protect her from this man when no one else believed me except the lesbian couple next door...

author: @grillsgrillsgrills
text:
Your testimony is so moving! I really appreciate the way you spoke about carceral feminism as a fellow abolitionist who has experienced DV. I've seen so many abolitionists throw around the term "carceral feminism" and they're so dismissive about it, and so often the way they present restorative justice is basically just "women are responsible for protecting and rehabilitating abusive men," and I've also seen a lot of abolitionists (lots of white ppl and lots of men) talk about how "carceral feminism" endangers men of color---which it absolutely does--but they never talk about  the safety risks for women of color whether or not we go to the police. And they never talk about how restorative justice requires that the abuser is willing to participate, and what are our options when they are unwilling to participate?
I want so badly to keep believing in restorative justice and rehabilitation! But I can't bear to see so many women of color being sacrificed, humiliated, and harassed for the sake of the men who hurt us!

author: @caitmonroe9349
text: Thank you for this. I was in a relationship for 4 years with a guy whose manic depression was only sporadically under control, and one night, he took away my phone and threatened me with a gun when he was extremely drunk. I didn't tell anyone for years afterwards because I was scared that the cops might be called and he might be shut out by our mutual friends. But at the same time, I've felt guilty because people I told later were often judgmental about me not reporting him. Thank you for both sharing your story and presenting such a clear abolitionist argument in cases of domestic violence

author: @tai9705
text: That testimony broke my heart. the horror and pain and cruelty you experienced at the hands of this disturbed man YET you continued to work overtime to express compassion and reinforce his humanity to the carceral state and your community even when you yourself were constantly being denied any humanity and compassion. You have such incredible strength I also believe in abolition but do not believe I could have maintained your level of integrity in the face of such injustice and cruelty. I absolutely understand the way mental illness can make good people behave in terrible ways wrt to both myself and my parents but again nothing close to the violence you experienced that sounded terrifying. for all my own trauma I never felt my life was in danger. I respect you advocating for someone sick even when they very nearly could have killed you. I had to pause the video and take a moment. I'm going to finish watching now and I sincerely hope that this man lives long enough to appreciate what you did for him and to pay it forward by being a better man and getting the counseling+medicine he desperately needed.

author: @Carmen_Gently
text:
I respect that you didnt want to share your story, as you dont want it to define you as a creator, abolitionist, or person. while my DV experience wasn't as traumatic as yours (at least, I dont think so), I also had former "friends' stand by my ex's side, despite that he was outwardly violent and mean to me in front of those same people. it was to the point where someone asked him "do you even LIKE her or want to be with her? it sure doesnt seem like it." 

when i abruptly left the apartment we shared because he punched me and threw me against a wall for not "wanting to go out to dinner with him after his long workday", I thought, for sure, that the friends we had, the same friends I invested so much time and energy into, the same friends I supported, would stand with me and help me. instead, they dropped me.... for a long time, i was confused about how I could be gaslit into thinking i was wrong, when someone clearly hurt me could be made out to be a saint. i still dont get it.

author: @5benn
text:
Your vulnerability in sharing this is really felt. I admire the bravery you show in speaking out about your experience, and the experiences of these women. 

As a man, and as someone who is white, your words are some of the best chances to understand circumstances that I will likely never have to deal with. I see you as a role model for the way you stand up for people, being able to articulate the business you stand on, and the way you do so despite the risk of people coming for you about it. 

Those are 3 goals I have for myself in life, and seeing examples of people living that matters a lot for me.

It wasn‚Äôt until years later that a few of them reached out to apologize once but it broke me that I was the one who was treated so awfully when I was the one getting kicked in the chest or shoved into walls, I never put my hands on him but to this day he calls me the crazy bitch to anyone who will listen..
